I saw myself more of a business person. I could not go on with C/C++ anymore. I wanted to strategize, be part of the company’s decision making hierarchy and also get into a different industry.So, I paused, asked myself what I really enjoyed, what could be my fulfilling career and how I could get there. Taking a break was not easy. Especially when money was coming my way and when my parents expected me to settle down. But I took a risk. I went for my higher studies at IIM-C. There I met so many people who had left their settled jobs to do this MBA. All of us had a few things in common: All of us knew what we wanted our career to be in the mid to long run; all of us were willing to let go of short term gains for long term results; all of us had to balance this professional break with our personal responsibilities. Some of my batchmates had children, some were married and about to have babies, some were about to get married. The challenges which the spouses had to face to ensure their husbands/wives did this one year course were not trivial. I was so impressed by them, that on campus, I wrote my first book “My Beloved’s MBA Plans” about how does one take an unconventional professional route while balancing personal responsibilities. The book has stories of 16 couples whose love faced the test of times when their husbands/wives were suddenly out of jobs and studying.A lot of us took an initial salary cut after her IIM-C MBA to get into a job we loved. Today, we are all happy we took that stance. I can proudly say I enjoy my work and feel passionate about every contribution I make to the world through my work. But if you want to eventually get into the business aspects of technology, an MBA acts as a bridge.
